Legal_Issue: Can the Registrar's decision to publish official marks by the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) be quashed due to lack of adoption and use?
Evidence_Assessment: The COC provided minimal evidence of adoption and use, relying on unsworn statements. The Registrar failed to investigate despite prior trademark applications by SYI Fund using similar marks.
Burden_of_Proof: On the COC to demonstrate adoption and use of the official mark
Credibility_Factor: Unsworn statements provided by COC considered insufficiently credible
Legal_Rule: Section 9(1)(n)(iii) prohibits adoption of any mark used as an official mark by a public authority; Registrar must verify evidence of adoption and use
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness in judicial review of administrative decisions
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of sufficient evidence of adoption and use by COC; prior use by SYI Fund
Outcome_on_Merits: COC cannot claim official marks without proper adoption and use
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior trademark applications by SYI Fund
Legal_Framework: Trade-marks Act, Canadian administrative law on judicial review
Defendant_Response: COC asserted use of 'SEE YOU IN' as official marks but failed to provide sufficient evidence
Outcome: Judicial review granted; Registrar's decision quashed

Legal_Issue: Whether the Registrar erred in accepting The Post Office's adoption and use of the MAILSORT mark
Procedural_Stage: Appeal under s. 56 of the Trade-marks Act; Judicial review under s. 18.1 of the Federal Court Act
Evidence_Assessment: No direct use of MAILSORT by The Post Office or its licensees in Canada before December 16, 1998
Burden_of_Proof: On The Post Office to demonstrate adoption and use in Canada
Legal_Rule: Under subparagraph 9(1)(n)(iii), a public authority must adopt and use a mark in Canada to qualify as an official mark
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, implied by judicial review context
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper adoption and use of MAILSORT mark in Canada
Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of direct use of MAILSORT in Canada prior to December 16, 1998
Remedy_Requested: Invalidation of MAILSORT as an official mark
Outcome: Appeal granted; MAILSORT mark status invalidated
Legal_Provision: s. 9(1)(n)(iii), s. 50, s. 56 of the Trade-marks Act; s. 18.1 of the Federal Court Act
Authority: The Post Office (UK), Registrar of Trade-marks

Legal_Issue: Whether the LCBO's use of 'Millennium' as an official mark conflicts with the applicant's trademark rights
Evidence_Assessment: LCBO provided insufficient evidence to support prior adoption and use of 'Millennium' as an official mark
Decision_Outcome: Court allowed the application, declaring the LCBO's official mark ineffective
Burden_of_Proof: On LCBO to prove prior adoption and use of the official mark
Credibility_Factor: Court found LCBO's claim unconvincing due to lack of substantiation
Legal_Rule: Official marks under subparagraph 9(1)(n)(iii) take precedence over trademarks if properly adopted and used
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness in judicial review of Registrar's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Conflict between LCBO's official mark and applicant's registered trademark
Outcome_on_Merits: Applicant succeeded; LCBO's official mark declared ineffective
Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence (or lack thereof) of LCBO's adoption and use of 'Millennium' as an official mark
Defendant_Response: LCBO claimed prior adoption and use of 'Millennium' as an official mark
Evidence_Type: Documentary and procedural evidence of use and adoption
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to set aside the Registrar's decision to publish the official mark
Outcome: Application allowed; official mark deemed ineffective
Authority: Registrar of Trademarks, Canadian Intellectual Property Office

Legal_Issue: Can the Ontario Foundation independently claim 'March of Dimes' as an official mark under s. 9(1)(n)(iii) of the Trade-marks Act?
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of independent adoption by the Ontario Foundation
Burden_of_Proof: On the Ontario Foundation to demonstrate independent adoption
Credibility_Factor: Licensed use does not equate to independent adoption
Legal_Rule: Under s. 9(1)(n)(iii), only public authorities that have adopted and used a mark can claim it as an official mark. A licensee's use does not constitute independent adoption.
Grounds_for_Claim: Ontario Foundation lacked standing to claim official mark due to licensed status
Outcome_on_Merits: Ontario Foundation cannot independently claim the marks
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of licensing agreement with National Council
Registrar's notices without proof of independent adoption
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, official marks regime
Defendant_Response: Registrar issued official mark notices to Ontario Foundation
Authority: Canadian Intellectual Property Office (Registrar of Trademarks)

Legal_Issue: Whether the United States Postal Service (USPS) is entitled to claim official marks under the Canadian Trade-marks Act as a public authority
Governing_Law: Subparagraph 9(1)(n)(iii) of the Canadian Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: USPS is an independent establishment of the U.S. government and not subject to Canadian governmental control
Decision_Outcome: USPS marks were declared not official; Registrar's decisions were set aside
Burden_of_Proof: On Canada Post Corporation to demonstrate USPS does not qualify as a public authority
Credibility_Factor: Court's determination of control by the Canadian government as key to public authority status
Legal_Rule: Only entities that are public authorities in Canada can claim official marks under subparagraph 9(1)(n)(iii) of the Trade-marks Act
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness in judicial review of administrative decisions
Grounds_for_Claim: USPS is not a Canadian public authority and therefore ineligible to hold official marks
Outcome_on_Merits: Application allowed; USPS cannot claim official marks
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature and structure of USPS as a U.S. government entity outside Canadian jurisdiction
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act, specifically provisions on official marks and public authorities
Defendant_Response: Registrar of Trademarks had granted official marks to USPS
Evidence_Type: Legal and institutional characterization of foreign governmental entities
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to set aside the Registrar's decision granting official marks to USPS

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of enforcement officer's decision to refuse deferral of removal
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 48(2)
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside due to reliance on outdated information
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to verify accuracy of information
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds, family circumstances, business interests
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of outdated information without verification
Crimes.Application_Error: Reliance on outdated and unverified data
Crimes.Application_Factor: Pregnant spouse, medical issues, pending H&C application

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of denial of deferral request
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 48(2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence accepted as basis for denial
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show special considerations
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s explanation of conduct during arrest
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Removal must be enforced as soon as reasonably practicable
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Family hardship, pending H&C application
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Request for deferral based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, no re-determination ordered

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Prior criminal behavior, intent to deceive
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: No mention of prior fraud convictions
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low flight risk but non-compliance concern
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish attempted fraud independently
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubt on intent due to lack of completed act
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: N/A – focus on removal, not punishment

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of refusal to defer removal post-conviction
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 48(2)
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Consistency of personal circumstances over time
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Removal orders enforced promptly unless exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and family considerations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Request for deferral based on family and health grounds
Crimes.Outcome: Decision overturned; new assessment required by different officer

Legal_Issue: Validity of the '967 patent
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies, affidavits, prior art (WO371), common knowledge, patent claims analysis
Legal_Rule: Patent must be novel, non-obvious, useful, and sufficiently disclosed
Grounds_for_Claim: Anticipation, obviousness, lack of utility, insufficiency, overbroad claims
Outcome_on_Merits: Application dismissed; patent invalid on grounds of anticipation, obviousness, and lack of utility
Key_Evidence_Considered: WO371 prior art, dosage range common knowledge, errors in disclosure, use of 'about' in claims
Evidence_Type: Affidavits, expert testimony, documentary evidence (prior art)
Remedy_Requested: Prohibition of Apotex from marketing generic modafinil
Outcome: Cephalon's application dismissed; Apotex allowed to proceed; costs awarded to Apotex with reduction
Legal_Provision: NOC Regulations, sections related to patent validity

Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officer erred by failing to consider the applicant's best interests as a child, separate from hardship considerations
Governing_Law: Subsection 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant lived comfortably in China with grandparents; regular contact with mother
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate unreasonable decision-making
Legal_Rule: Subsection 25(1) requires consideration of humanitarian and compassionate grounds, including the best interests of a child, but such interests are not separate from hardship considerations
Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds for permanent residence, based on best interests of the child
Outcome_on_Merits: Visa Officer’s decision upheld as reasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Living conditions in China, relationship with mother, support from grandparents
Defendant_Response: Visa Officer considered hardship and best interests adequately
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal circumstances, family ties
Remedy_Requested: Permanent residence in Canada on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Authority: Federal Court (implied by judicial review context)

Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in applying the standard of reasonableness to the RPD's findings
Evidence_Assessment: Credibility assessment of the applicant
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected refugee claim; RAD initially upheld, decision set aside on judicial review
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish refugee status
Credibility_Factor: RPD found credibility issues with the applicant's testimony
Legal_Rule: RAD must correct legal errors or palpable and overriding factual errors
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard misapplied by RAD; correctness expected for legal errors, palpable and overriding error for facts
Grounds_for_Claim: Applicant claimed persecution and sought refugee protection
Outcome_on_Merits: Not determined; case remanded for reconsideration
Legal_Framework: IRPA, appellate standards, judicial review principles
Defendant_Response: RPD denied claim based on credibility; RAD initially upheld decision
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn RAD decision
Outcome: Judicial review granted; matter referred back to a new RAD panel
Legal_Provision: Sections of IRPA governing RAD appeals and standard of review

Legal_Issue: Whether Genpharm's allegations of invalidity and non-infringement are justified
Evidence_Assessment: Analysis of prior art, product formulation, expert opinions, inventive step
Burden_of_Proof: On generic manufacturer (Genpharm) to substantiate invalidity or non-infringement
Credibility_Factor: Strength of AstraZeneca's evidence on inventive step and specific use
Legal_Rule: Generic must provide detailed statement of legal and factual basis for invalidity/non-infringement claims
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness of allegations based on evidence and law
Grounds_for_Claim: Prior art, differences in formulation, alleged lack of novelty/inventive step
Outcome_on_Merits: AstraZeneca succeeded; patents upheld as valid and potentially infringed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Patents '693, '377, '668, '762, expert testimony, prior art references
Defendant_Response: Genpharm challenged validity and infringement of AstraZeneca's patents
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, expert reports, patent specifications
Remedy_Requested: Order prohibiting issuance of NOC to Genpharm
Outcome: Order granted; NOC prohibited until patent expiration
Legal_Provision: Sections under the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations

Legal_Issue: Whether the tribunal erred in dismissing the complaint regarding the use of a retracted reference
Evidence_Assessment: The tribunal found no evidence of unreliability or bias in the retracted reference
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate unreasonable decision-making
Credibility_Factor: Mr. Burke's retracted reference was assessed for reliability and bias
Legal_Rule: The tribunal must determine if the reference is sufficiently familiar with the candidate's work; abuse of authority includes bad faith or personal favoritism
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged abuse of authority due to reliance on a retracted reference
Authority: Attorney General of Canada (named as sole respondent)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Comply with a Recognizance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of continued detention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of immigration detention decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Past gang involvement, credibility issues, unproven allegations
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Crown/Board to justify continued detention
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Board's decision can be overturned if findings unsupported or legal analysis incorrect
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Intermediate standard for mixed fact and law questions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable assessment of danger and alternatives to detention
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Past gang ties, lack of credible bondspersons, rehabilitation efforts
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged detention as unjustified and disproportionate
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, new detention review ordered
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of continued detention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of immigration detention decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Past gang involvement, credibility concerns, unproven allegations
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Board to justify continued detention
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Decision subject to judicial review if findings lack evidentiary support or legal error

Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient consideration of current dangerousness and alternatives

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued he was not a current risk and suitable for release
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and release on bail

Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Danger to the public, criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Link between past conduct and potential future risk
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Board record, police reports, applicant testimony
Crimes.Outcome: Court found decision unreasonable, ordered new hearing
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Perceived ongoing danger and flight risk
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to adequately assess current risk and alternatives

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Insufficient analysis of current danger and alternatives
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Detention extended based on public safety concerns
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged drug trafficking and gang-related activity
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Prior involvement in organized crime and drug offenses
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Connection between past criminal behavior and potential reoffending
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Police records, Board proceedings, applicant statements
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, new detention review ordered
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to meaningfully consider rehabilitation and less restrictive options

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the removal officer erred in refusing to defer removal
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 48(2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer considered children's best interests, risk factors, humanitarian & compassionate factors, and pending ministerial relief
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show patent unreasonableness
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Standard of review is patent unreasonableness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to consider family, risk, humanitarian, and pending relief factors
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued officer failed to adequately consider relevant factors
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; no certification of questions
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 48(2), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence linking general conditions in Haiti to personal situation

Legal_Issue: Is the trademark 'DELI SNACK' registrable under paragraph 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act?
Evidence_Assessment: The term 'DELI SNACK' is used in commerce for similar seafood-based snack products
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate distinctiveness or non-descriptiveness
Credibility_Factor: Evidence of common usage in the marketplace
Legal_Rule: A trademark is not registrable if it is clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive of the character or quality of the wares
Grounds_for_Claim: The trademark 'DELI SNACK' is clearly descriptive of seafood-based delicatessen snack foods
Outcome_on_Merits: The appeal was dismissed; the trademark remains unregistrable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Commercial use of the term 'DELI SNACK' for similar products
Defendant_Response: The Registrar rejected the application on grounds of descriptiveness

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Foreseeable risk of violence after verbal altercation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reliable based on officer documentation and procedural gaps

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of Duty of Care under Corrections and Conditional Release Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether CSC breached its duty of care to ensure inmate safety
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Officer reports and security deficiencies deemed credible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: CSC must take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable harm
Standard_of_Review: Palpable and overriding error for factual findings
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to act on pre-indicators of violence and inadequate security
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules, Corrections and Conditional Release Act
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal dismissed; $12,000 awarded to plaintiff

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection under Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether there are serious reasons to believe the applicant committed burglary in Florida prior to entering Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Police reports and charges were considered, but conflicting evidence existed regarding intent and value of stolen items
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD's decision found the applicant entered a dwelling with intent to steal
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Serious reasons to believe the commission of a serious non-political crime
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Conflicting evidence on intent and item value affected credibility assessment
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A person is excluded from refugee protection if they committed a serious non-political crime outside the country of refuge prior to admission
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged burglary and grand theft in Florida
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Unreasonable due to lack of clear evidence on intent for burglary
Key_Evidence_Considered: Value and nature of stolen items
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Disputed intent to commit theft during entry
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of RPD decision and reconsideration
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed; matter remanded for reconsideration by a different board panel
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court of Canada

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection under Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether there are serious reasons to believe the applicant committed grand theft in Florida prior to entering Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Unclear evidence regarding the value of stolen items and intent to commit theft
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD concluded the applicant committed grand theft based on charges, but evidence was insufficient
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Serious reasons to believe the commission of a serious non-political crime
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Doubt cast on the clarity of intent and valuation of stolen property
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A person is excluded from refugee protection if they committed a serious non-political crime outside the country of refuge prior to admission
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged grand theft in Florida involving property over $5000
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Insufficient evidence to support seriousness or intent for grand theft
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Contested the value of stolen items and criminal intent
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of RPD decision and reconsideration
Crimes.Outcome: Decision overturned; case remanded for further consideration by a different board panel
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court of Canada

Legal_Provision: Section 12, 14 of the Indian Band Election Regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to investigate credible allegations of electoral misconduct
Legal_Issue: evidentiary standard in election appeals
Governing_Law: Sections 12, 14 of the Indian Band Election Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: focused narrowly on direct exchange of alcohol for votes
ignored broader evidence of corruption
Decision_Outcome: dismissed appeal due to insufficient evidence under incorrect standard
Burden_of_Proof: appearance of wrongdoing required, but higher standard applied
Legal_Rule: proof of appearance of wrongdoing suffices
Grounds_for_Claim: vote-buying with alcohol
voter influence
Key_Evidence_Considered: investigator's report showing appearances of misconduct

Governing_Law: s.14 of Indian Band Election Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: evidence of alcohol supply near election ignored due to lack of direct confirmation
Burden_of_Proof: appearance of wrongdoing standard not applied
Legal_Rule: appearance of wrongdoing sufficient under s.14
Grounds_for_Claim: supplying alcohol as vote-buying

Crimes.Crime_Name: Contravention of Indian Band Election Regulations

Legal_Provision_Involved: Sections 12, 14 of Indian Band Election Regulations
Grounds_for_Claim: corrupt practices including vote-buying and voter influence
Jurisdiction: First Nation elections under federal regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Corrupt practices in connection with an election
Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 12, 14 of Indian Band Election Regulations
Application_Facts: alleged use of alcohol to influence voters
Evidentiary_Deficiency: requirement for actual proof instead of appearance
Legal_Standard_Applied: incorrectly required proof of actual wrongdoing
Decision_Rationale: failure to apply statutory standard under s.14

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Outcome: Decision on complicity quashed
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged membership in MQM and complicity in crimes against humanity
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable finding due to lack of personal involvement or intent

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicant's association with MQM/APMSO constitutes membership under IRPA
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Board to establish membership by credible evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Supporting documents and testimonies deemed credible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Broad interpretation of 'membership' in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged membership in MQM and complicity in crimes against humanity
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review partially dismissed; deportation upheld under section 34(1)(f)

Crime_Name: Administrative Error in Granting Leave to Appeal
Legal_Issue: Whether the Pension Appeals Board's decision to grant leave to appeal without following proper procedures and providing reasons is valid?
Decision_Outcome: The decision to grant leave is quashed, and the matter is remanded for re-determination with a requirement to provide reasons.
Legal_Rule: Under Rule 4 of the Pension Appeals Board Rules, an application for leave to appeal must include specific details. Discretionary decisions require reasons, even if not explicitly mandated by statute.
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper granting of leave to appeal due to lack of procedural compliance and absence of recorded reasons.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Mr. Montesano did not submit the required materials under Rule 4.
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of the decision and remanding for re-determination with instructions to provide reasons.
Outcome: Decision quashed, case sent back for re-determination with instructions to provide reasons.
Legal_Provision: Rule 4 of the Pension Appeals Board Rules

Legal_Issue: Scope of permissible discovery questions
Governing_Law: Rules governing discovery and prior case law
Evidence_Assessment: Relevance and timing of discovery questions
Decision_Outcome: Defendant not required to answer post-1990 market research or patent validity questions; follow-up questions on prior art and sales allowed
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff to demonstrate relevance of discovery requests
Legal_Rule: Relevant discovery questions must advance a party's case or damage the opponent's; irrelevant or expert opinion-seeking questions are disallowed
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged patent infringement
Outcome_on_Merits: Limited discovery granted; costs awarded proportionally
Key_Evidence_Considered: Market research (post-1990), prior art, sales data, patent validity inquiries
Legal_Framework: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure (discovery rules)
Defendant_Response: Refused to answer certain discovery questions as irrelevant
Remedy_Requested: Compel defendant to answer discovery questions
Outcome: Plaintiff granted limited additional oral discovery; costs awarded proportionally
Legal_Provision: Discovery rules related to relevance and scope
Authority: Court applying discovery rules and precedent

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CDS decision on administrative actions
Crimes.Governing_Law: National Defence Act, Canadian military law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Limited evidence to support harassment claim
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: CDS acknowledged some grievances but found others unsubstantiated
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Reasonableness standard for mixed questions of fact and law
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unfair administrative actions post-deployment
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Personnel Evaluation Report, repatriation letter, grievance records
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Military grievance process and judicial review principles
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CDS partially addressed grievances but maintained some actions
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Rewrite PER, remove repatriation letter, declare harassment
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed, no costs awarded

Crimes.Crime_Name: Conduct to the prejudice of good order and discipline
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of remedies provided by CDS
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Administrative actions reviewed with partial cancellation
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: CDS exercised discretion within acceptable bounds
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Reasonableness standard in military administrative decisions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Severe administrative penalties following accidental discharges
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Disciplinary records, grievance findings, CDS decision
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Military justice and administrative review system
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CDS canceled some actions, retained justified ones
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed, decision upheld

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CDS decision on grievances related to firearm incidents
Crimes.Governing_Law: National Defence Act, military administrative law
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review after internal grievance process
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Incident reports, PER, procedural fairness concerns noted
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: CDS decision found reasonable despite some procedural issues
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show decision was unreasonable
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: CDS recognized bias in PER but upheld certain documents
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Reasonableness standard applied to military expertise-based decisions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Biased evaluation and penalties after accidental discharges
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Firearm incident reports, personnel file, grievance board findings
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CDS revised some actions, maintained others as justified
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed, CDS decision upheld

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant made false statements or misrepresented facts in immigration application
Crimes.Outcome: Application rejected; judicial review initiated over procedural concerns
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned applicant's credibility based on undisclosed evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Undisclosed documents, allegations of organized crime ties

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Ms. Mueller was absent from Canada for 783 days during the required period
Maintained employment with the Canadian High Commission abroad
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet physical presence requirement but claimed constructive residency
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Court failed to properly apply or explain the centralized mode of living test
Evidence_Used: Employment records with Canadian High Commission
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Court did not clearly assess or explain rejection of applicant's evidence
Decision_Outcome: Denial of citizenship application by Citizenship Court
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Court decision
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of residency claim by a different Citizenship Court judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralized mode of living test for constructive residency
Decision_Rationale: Significant ties to Canada may establish constructive residency despite absence
Court erred in not applying or explaining the legal test for constructive residency

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in reliance on extrinsic evidence
Outcome: Decision quashed, case remitted for re-determination
Credibility_Assessment: Inferred based on undisclosed university rankings and employment details
Evidence_Type: Extrinsic evidence (university rankings, past employment, country conditions)
Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds for permanent residence
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of undisclosed extrinsic evidence affecting hardship assessment
Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires disclosure and opportunity to respond
Application_Factor: Wealth and likelihood of hardship in Bangladesh

Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA provisions related to work permits
Application_Facts: Applicants engaged in work without valid authorization
Claimant_Status: Applicants under humanitarian and compassionate consideration
Misrepresentation_Element: Potential credibility concerns due to unauthorized work
Evidence_Used: University rankings, country conditions, internet-sourced data
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to disclose key evidence to applicants
Credibility_Assessment: Assessed through undisclosed background and country condition data
Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for other issues
Decision_Rationale: Undisclosed extrinsic evidence used in assessing credibility and hardship
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, reviewed by Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Use of undisclosed extrinsic evidence in decision
Evidence_Assessment: Internet-sourced information about applicant's background and country conditions
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to establish humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires disclosure of evidence used
Grounds_for_Claim: Denial based on undisclosed evidence affecting hardship assessment
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached due to procedural unfairness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Undisclosed internet-based evidence on wealth and conditions in Bangladesh
Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles of procedural fairness

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 876 days, failing the 1,095-day physical presence requirement in the four years preceding application
Residency_Compliance: Failed – did not meet 1,095-day physical presence test
Procedural_Issue: Appeal based on the record before the Citizenship Judge, governed by Federal Courts Rules
Evidence_Used: Record of absences and presence in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review allowing citizenship application to proceed
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge correctly applied the mandatory physical presence test; no obligation to consider qualitative factors where statutory numerical threshold was unmet

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Egypt; PRRA rejected due to lack of new evidence showing worsened country conditions; officer failed to consider 2004-2005 human rights reports indicating deterioration
Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident or Protected Person seeking refugee protection
Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer failed to compare country condition changes between 2002 and 2004-2005; inadequate assessment of new evidence
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports from 2004-2005 documenting human rights abuses in Egypt
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of comparative analysis between prior conditions and new evidence on country conditions
Credibility_Assessment: Not directly challenged; focus was on objective country condition evidence
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision found patently unreasonable
Relief_Sought: Reassessment of PRRA based on updated country condition evidence
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different PRRA panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness standard in administrative law
Decision_Rationale: Officer's failure to consider credible evidence of deteriorating human rights conditions rendered the decision perverse and outside acceptable limits

Application_Facts: Applicant is a Haitian businessman claiming persecution due to perceived wealth; generalized violence in Haiti affects all citizens similarly
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) decision
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over IRB decisions
Evidence_Used: IRB findings on generalized risk in Haiti
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating personalized risk distinct from general population
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; risk not deemed personalized
Relief_Sought: Overturn of IRB decision, recognition of refugee protection
Remedy_Sought: Certification of legal question for broader consideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Personalized risk under Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Risk faced by applicant is generalized and not specific to a protected subgroup; does not meet threshold for personalized risk under IRPA
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminal Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Nasso, convicted of extortion, sought a Temporary Resident Permit (TRP) to enter Canada for business interests.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application argued statutory misinterpretation and unreasonableness of visa officer's decision.
Decision_Outcome: Visa officer denied TRP due to lack of compelling need and no undue hardship from exclusion.
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 24(1) of IRPA allows discretion to issue TRPs in exceptional circumstances.
Decision_Rationale: Officer’s decision was reasonable and aligned with Section 24(1); no compelling need or undue hardship established.

Risk_Assessment: Risk of recidivism cited by visa officer
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to establish inadmissibility under IRPA

Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate new risk conditions
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 115 and Section 101(1)(a)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed rape-related scars as new evidence; RPD had previously considered rape allegations; no significant new evidence or personalized risk identified in Albania
Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of consideration of new evidence on gender-based violence and procedural fairness in PRRA decision
Evidence_Used: Rape-related scars, allegations of gender-based violence, risk of blood feud in Albania
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No significant new evidence presented; prior allegations already assessed by RPD
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found no credible, individualized risk based on new evidence
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no error found in Officer's decision
Relief_Sought: Overturn of PRRA denial, stay of removal
Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question of law; judicial review of PRRA decision
Decision_Rationale: PRRA not an appeal of RPD decision; requires demonstration of changed circumstances; no new evidence of personalized risk established

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 840 days of physical presence in Canada within four years preceding application
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day requirement; shortfall of 347 days
Procedural_Issue: Appeal under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act; adequacy of reasons provided by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Documentation submitted by applicant to support residency claim
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Additional documentation rejected as insufficient for alternative tests (quality of residence, centralization of mode of existence)
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; applicant remains ineligible for citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Strict count of days test; alternative tests (quality of residence, centralization of mode of existence) considered but not satisfied
Decision_Rationale: Judge correctly applied residency requirement and provided adequate reasons; no error in rejecting alternative tests or blending methodologies

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for 621 days out of the required 1095 days in the four years preceding application.
Absence due to spousal support during husband's temporary work assignment abroad.
Prior to absence, applicant lived and worked in Canada, paid taxes, and established a home.
Residency_Compliance: Insufficient physical presence but maintained strong ties to Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to Federal Court - Trial Division following denial by Citizenship judge
Evidence_Used: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Proof of home establishment in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Citizenship judge failed to properly consider temporary nature of absence and ties to Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-year residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act with allowance for temporary absences
Decision_Rationale: Absence was temporary and justified by spousal support.
Applicant maintained significant ties to Canada.
Citizenship judge erred in failing to properly assess the temporary nature of the absence and the strength of the applicant's connections to Canada.
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge, Federal Court - Trial Division

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for all but 117 days in the four-year period preceding the application
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – only 117 days of physical presence, short of 1,095-day requirement
Procedural_Issue: Appeal based on the record before the citizenship judge, governed by Federal Courts Rules
Evidence_Used: Record of applicant's physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documentation or proof of physical presence meeting 1,095-day threshold
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge correctly applied the physical presence test; applicant failed to meet statutory residency requirement

Legal_Issue: Did the Board misinterpret s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act and fail to apply it properly?
Outcome: The application is allowed, and the matter is returned for redetermination by a new panel due to the Board's legal error.
Basis_of_Claim: Mr. Jiminez claimed refugee status based on past persecution in El Salvador, but the Board rejected his claim.
Application_Error: Focused on current psychological state post-brain injury rather than nature of past persecution
Evidence_Ignored: Severity and appalling nature of past torture in El Salvador
Legal_Standard: Whether the Board correctly applied s. 2(3)
Application_Factor: Compelling reasons arising from past persecution

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Board failed to consider severity of past persecution
Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a newly constituted panel
Evidence_Source: Testimony of Mr. Jiminez regarding torture
Basis_for_Decision: Severe torture suffered in the past
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to assess compelling reasons under s. 2(3)
